It is obvious that both the female egg and the male sperm have a form of life but no one would call either a "person". When they unite to form a zygote we certainly have a form of life. There is a potential person there and a great many people would claim that it actually is a person.
 
 Let us grant for a moment that the zygote is a person and let us call that person Mary. Now, we all know that a zygote develops into an embryo through the process of cell division. Every now and again the first cell division does not produce a two celled embryo but rather a second zygote --- twins. Did Mary suddenly become two persons? Was Mary two persons to begin with? Was Mary even a person to begin with?
 
 Let us set those questions aside for the moment and grant that the second zygote is also a person whom we shall call Margaret. It is entirely possible that one or both of these zygotes could divide again to result in triplets, quadruplets, quintuplets etc. The same question applies as to whether one person can became two, three or more persons. When does a person become a person?
 
 These questions might be difficult enough but now it becomes even more complex. Rarely the two zygotes (Mary and Margaret) merge together again to form a two celled embryo. This is called a "chimera". Who is this new embryo? Is it Mary or is it Margaret? This new embryo, this chimera, let us call it Mary, develops to term and is born. There is now no question at all that Mary is indeed a person. But here is the odd thing, some of the organs of Mary carry her genes but other organs carry the genes of her twin sister Margaret. So Margaret continues to exist within Mary or perhaps it is Mary within Margaret. Do we have two persons within a single body?
 
 These very serious questions of personhood arise only if we assume that the soul is infused at conception (as many Christian groups do) and that the brand new zygote is fully a person. Is there a more reasonable understanding? I believe there is. Personally I believe that the developing fetus becomes a person only when it is able to survive outside the womb. This happens very late in the second trimester. For this reason I am against abortion beyond the twentieth week. Otherwise I believe that abortion should be legal, it should be safe, it should be available and it should be the woman's informed choice but most important of all --- it should be rare.

It's a person when God knits them together in some way in their mother's womb (Psalm 139:13). And even before:

 before you were born I set you apart; 
 I appointed you as a prophet to the nations."

The wording of this thread intrigues me. I see that many here jump in and start arguing about "when" a person begins. Is it not possible to define it in the opposite? Aren't things able to be understood by looking at a thing and saying "this is not....." as well as looking at them and saying "this is...."?
 
 I can look at a basketball sized vegetable that is orange in color and say "This is a pumpkin". I can also define it and say "This is not a tennis racket".
 
 I say this in context of the title of this thread. If you can define a person by "when" it begins, certainly you will be able to define it in terms of "when" it ends. 
 
 Since time is a relevant thing, it is defined as a point in space. Movement. If nothing moves, time doesn't either. If things move forward, time does also. If things move backwards, time does as well.
 
 So let's look at a bouncing baby boy at the age of one day. Certainly, this baby is defined as a person, right? Wouldn't ending it's life be murder at this point? Let's go back to yesterday. This little baby has just been born and it's umbilical has just been cut. Is it still a person? Nothing has changed in the previous day. It is still the baby it will be tomorrow. Let's take a minute by minute reversal. Let's go back just another few minutes. Now the umbilical cord is still attached. Is it still a person? Let's slow down now. If you cam imagine the little baby turning upside down and heading feet first towards the birth canal, has it stopped being a person? Let's slow down a little slower. Second by second. We are talking about when a person begins, right? It now returns, feet first into the mother. We've established that it is still a person as the umbilical reattaches. Now, as we revert, second by second, the feet enter...is it still a person? Let's slow down to a crawl. Imagine a film reel going backwards frame by frame as the baby returns toward the womb. In go the knees. Now it's up to it's waist, hands, arms, neck.........chin.....nose.....we slowly see the head start to dissapear....
 
 Pick any second and tell me when to kill it.
 
 After all, if it becomes a person at a particular split second going forward in time, it will certainly stop being one at some point going backward, right? I would really like to know, not only the moment that it stops being a person, but what changed from the moment just preceeding it that caused it's humanity to stop existing.

Let me "show you" something:
 
 Continuum fallacy - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

After all, if it becomes a person at a particular split second going forward in time, it will certainly stop being one at some point going backward, right? I would really like to know, not only the moment that it stops being a person, but what changed from the moment just preceeding it that caused it's humanity to stop existing.

 Well, if you look at when we draw a line through when the continuum ends, you get permenant cessation of brain function. That sounds like a good line to draw for the 'start' point, too - although I agree with you that it is a continuum. Hence each person has their own right to choose.

 Someone asked on yahoo, is sperm is alive and if so, is it considered a life form?
 
 This was chosen as best answer:
 
 
Sperm cells, like many other cells produced by the human body, are functionally alive. They are nourished within the testes and epididymis until they are released via ejaculation. Once the sperm leaves the male body, however, its days are numbered. Sperm carry enough energy to complete the task of reaching the ovum and fertilizing it, but they lack the capacity to take on new nutrients. If a sperm cell fails to fuse with an ovum, it will eventually die and decompose.
 
 Sperm cells are difficult to think of as alive, but they meet the criteria, and so they are. I hope that helps. Good luck!

 4 Let us grant for a moment that the zygote is a person and let us call that person Mary.  Let us set those questions aside for the moment and grant that the second zygote is also a person whom we shall call Margaret.  These questions might be difficult enough but now it becomes even more complex. Rarely the two zygotes (Mary and Margaret) merge together again to form a two celled embryo. This is called a "chimera". Who is this new embryo? Is it Mary or is it Margaret? This new embryo, this chimera, let us call it Mary, develops to term and is born. So Margaret continues to exist within Mary or perhaps it is Mary within Margaret. Do we have two persons within a single body?
 
 These very serious questions of personhood arise only if we assume that the soul is infused at conception (as many Christian groups do) and that the brand new zygote is fully a person. Is there a more reasonable understanding? I believe there is. Personally I believe that the developing fetus becomes a person only when it is able to survive outside the womb.  Unfortunately dictionaries, too, are subject to abuse. Example:
 
 Claw: a sharp, usually curved, nail on the foot of an animal.
 nail: a slender, typically rod-shaped rigid piece of metal
 foot: foot soldiers; infantry.
 animal: an inhuman person; brutish or beastlike person.
 
 Using these definitions, we can see that a 'claw' is a sharp piece of metal attached to any infantry commanded by a beast.
 
 As for 'life'; the possibilities are endless, especially if you wish to be inclusive.
 
 Steeeeve has it right; to pretend that you aren't attributing 'value' to things simply because you use some dictionary definitions is not entirely consistent. Once that is agreed, we fall back into trying to decide whose 'value' is the correct one - hence the topic of the thread. I wouldn't agree that atheists have 'no way to judge value', however - it's simply that we have our own internal moral compasses, rather than your perceived 'external' one. Before you criticise that as being changeable and unsound, I remind you of the vast myriad of conflicting moralities that Abrahamic religion has spawned. From an atheist viewpoint, all theists see when they consult their external moral compass is a reflection of their internal one; not the other way around.

With an external compass you have no choice on what is North. Keep in mind this doesn't state one is right and one is wrong.

Unfortunately dictionaries, too, are subject to abuse. Example:
 
 Claw: a sharp, usually curved, nail on the foot of an animal.
 nail: a slender, typically rod-shaped rigid piece of metal
 foot: foot soldiers; infantry.
 animal: an inhuman person; brutish or beastlike person.
 
 Using these definitions, we can see that a 'claw' is a sharp piece of metal attached to any infantry commanded by a beast.
 
 As for 'life'; the possibilities are endless, especially if you wish to be inclusive.

 Your fallacy is called "Apples and Oranges." 
 
 "apples and oranges - drawing comparisons between events or sets of circumstances that seem to share a common denominator but are in fact distinct from one another by virtue of having occurred during different time periods, in different places, under different socio-economic conditions, to different groups of people, etc., can lead to the incorrect assumption that, just because something is true under one set of circumstances, it will necessarily hold true for all circumstances of a similar sort. The act of making such comparisons is sometimes referred to as "comparing apples and oranges."

Mangling the language does not change the fact that your position is a travesty.

Mangling the language does not change the fact that your position is a travesty.

 
 My previous post (#91) is the only sane, rational position to take. It is the various positions promoted by mainstream society that are a travesty of Truth, justice, sanity, rationality, and nature.
 
 Perhaps we might hear exactly why you wrongly believe that My position is a travesty.

My previous post (#91) is the only sane, rational position to take. It is the various positions promoted by mainstream society that are a travesty of Truth, justice, sanity, rationality, and nature.
 
 Perhaps we might hear exactly why you wrongly believe that My position is a travesty.

 
 Mabye it's because you hate a society you obviously know nothing about, you claim victory when you answer nobodies questions, you claim superiority when you think you win by yelling louder than your opponent, you dismiss an opponent you can't beat as a sixteen year old, you say society advocates certain viewpoints when there are plenty of people who don't hold those veiwpoints, you blame your own failure on a societal heirarchy when you can't even prove it exists, whenever you talk about society you don't provide a lick of evidence, and you are extremely arrogant, for a start. :)

Until society and the legislature chooses to recognize the fetus as a true human being, a person, and a sentient entity, then you simply don't have a leg to stand on. You can argue until you're blue in the face, but it doesn't amount to **** if the ones in charge don't agree with you.
 
 I win.

Prophets called from the womb:
 
 Samson:
 
 Then the woman came and told her husband, saying, "A man of God came to me and his appearance was like the appearance of the angel of God, very awesome. And I did not ask him where he came from, nor did he tell me his name. "But he said to me, `Behold, you shall conceive and give birth to a son, and now you shall not drink wine or strong drink nor eat any unclean thing, for the boy shall be a Nazirite to God from the womb to the day of his death.'" (Judges 13:6-7, see also Judges 16:17) 
 
 Jesus (prophecy):
 
 Listen to Me, O islands, And pay attention, you peoples from afar. The LORD called Me from the womb; From the body of My mother He named Me. (Isaiah 49:1) 
 
 And now says the LORD, who formed Me from the womb to be His Servant, To bring Jacob back to Him, in order that Israel might be gathered to Him (For I am honored in the sight of the LORD, And My God is My strength), (Isaiah 49:5) 
 
 Yet Thou art He who didst bring me forth from the womb; Thou didst make me trust when upon my mother's breasts. Upon Thee I was cast from birth; Thou hast been my God from my mother's womb. (Psalm 22:9-10) 
 
 Jeremiah:
 
 "Before I formed you in the womb I knew you, And before you were born I consecrated you; I have appointed you a prophet to the nations." (Jeremiah 1:5) 
 
 John the Baptist:
 
 "For he will be great in the sight of the Lord, and he will drink no wine or liquor; and he will be filled with the Holy Spirit, while yet in his mother's womb." (Luke 1:15) 
 
 Paul:
 
 But when He who had set me apart, even from my mother's womb, and called me through His grace, was pleased (Galatians 1:15)
 
 The Bible and Abortion - The Biblical Basis for a Prolife Position
 
 Also note Psalm 139:13.
 
 STOP KILLING THE INNOCENT BABIES.

Hello,
 I would like to share a piece of reading material for thought that I found @ my church the other day. It goes like this....
 "I Too Had Love To Give"
 I'd have been there for you when you grew old & grey.
 Now all that you will have is pain & remorse untold.
 What is not in earthly pleasure that you & Daddy made me?
 Why then, for worldly treasure the farewell that you bade me?
 When you killed me, no tears, just a sigh of relief, but one day,
 Dearest Mother, you will know the deepest grief. Why was I not
 Adopted? Could not someone else enjoy watching me grow up 
 to be a delightful girl or boy? Why did you slay me Mother?
 Why not let me live? You would have loved me Mother for
 I too had love to give!
 He sent his only precious son to teach us all "The way" still we kill the unborn ones, It happens every day!
 You didn't make it, Unborn Child. They wouldn't let you be. They just expelled a blob of cells.
 It's "The New Morality"
 When you stand before your maker @ the end of your worldly existence & GOD asks you..
 Where is your child? Why isn't it neither here or there? That is where you'll find the answer
 Was it a human being? Or a blob of cells!

People are flying to China to get a baby when there are plenty right here, if you don't believe me ask that wonderful group Planned Parenthood.

It's funny how the bible can support any position you want it to...
 
 THE PRO-CHOICE ACTION NETWORK
 
 
The Hebrew word for human being or living soul is nephesh, which is also the word for "breathing." Nephesh occurs over 700 times in the Bible as the identifying factor in human life. Obviously, fetuses do not breath and therefore cannot be considered as human beings according to the Bible. Here is another verse that reinforces this conclusion.

 
 There's also a bunch of verses and other boring bible stuff in there, like the punishment for a causing a miscarriage in the Old Testament is only a fine (as opposed to murderers who are put to death). (Exodus 21:22-25).

It's funny how the bible can support any position you want it to...
 

 
 When you're spiritually dead that's the conclusion you might draw.

 I'm way more interested in getting past this nonsense and getting some serious funding and support for embryonic stem cell research. 
 
 Like it or not, abortion is legal and that's not going to change any time soon. And while I don't agree with the Pro-Life view, I can see where they are coming from, and I understand why they don't want their tax money contributing to what they believe is murder, but I just wish they could see that stem cell research could save millions of lives.
